author: pk910
content:
Heya,
Where are new execution layer blocks generated post merge?
Is it still the execution layer client (geth / ...) or the consensus layer (lighthouse / ...)?

author: pk910
content:
If I understood correctly it's still the execution layer client and the beacon chain just references the hash?
So how does the fee-recipient address work?
As it's a beacon node setting it gets passed to the execution layer client and a new block is generated with it?
Is that also the case for fallback nodes (infura) or will they just build blocks with their own recipient?
How can the consenus layer client be sure its not referencing a "bad block"?

I assume eg. ifura builds blocks with their own fee recipient when using their beacon-node (eth2 api) as fallback for validator clients?

author: m.kalinin
content: It's generated by execution layer client with requests to do this coming from consensus layer client. Then CL client obtains generated payload, incorporates it into a beacon block it is producing and sends a beacon block into the network.

author: m.kalinin
content: You may see it here, an entire execution payload including feeRecipient is a part of a beacon block https://beaconchain.kintsugi.themerge.dev/block/54559

author: pk910
content:
ahh, thanks üëç 
but how can the consensus layer client be sure to get a valid block from the execution layer (eg. in fallback cases)?

author: m.kalinin
content: CL client passes `suggestedFeeRecipient` and it may be supplanted by a block builder which in this case should pay a validator to the `suggestedFeeRecipient` address via separate transaction

author: m.kalinin
content: It can't be sure but it will know about an invalid payload right away, because CL will `executePayload` using its local EL despite of the building block mechanism it uses

author: pk910
content: ah, so it's then also a bad consensus block when a bad execution layer block is referenced and get's thrown away in the consensus chain

author: m.kalinin
content: If say builder built an invalid payload and relay offered this payload to a validator it will be known right after validator executed this block with local EL client. Right, invalid payload invalidates an entire beacon block

author: pk910
content: will it be slashed when a invalid CL block (because of invalid EL block) is built or is it just a "missed" block in that case?

author: m.kalinin
content: it's not a slashable condition as it currently is, it will be missed
